intro: Daucus scariosus, commonly known as the sandparsley, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the western United States and parts of Canada. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in clusters, typically in late spring to early summer. Its root system is adapted to survive in dry conditions, allowing it to thrive in sandy or rocky soils. Daucus scariosus is often found in disturbed areas and is considered a pioneer species in ecological succession.
